sn8.9:1.2: Koṇḍañña gained his nickname as he was the first person to realize the Dhamma after the Buddha (SN 56.11:14.3). His absence was due to his love of solitude, as expressed in his verses (Thag 15.1:0.4). Due to this, he features rarely in the early texts, but the Buddha once saw him meditating (Ud 7.6), and praised him as the senior mendicant (AN 1.188:1.1).
sn8.9:3.1: Used more generally of early disciples at SN 16.5:5.3.
sn8.9:3.4: Not the three consisting of body, mind, and attachments, for this is only found in later texts (Mnd 2:11.2). Perhaps the three consisting of ethics, view, and ending of defilements (AN 3.93:5.1). But since the absorptions are often called “blissful meditations” (SN 21.4:3.3) and “seclusion” (MN 64:9.2), it’s more satisfying to read the two phrases together.
